Duty.origin: [Anglo-French deuté indebtedness, obligation, from deu owing, due, from Old French see due ]

du·ties.definition: [Anglo-Frenchindebtedness, obligation, fromowing, due, from Old French see]

1.definition: tasks, service, or functions that arise from one's position [performing a police officer's]a period of being on duty see also

2.definition: an obligation assumed (as by contract) or imposed by law to conduct oneself in conformance with a certain standard or to act in a particular way [ of good faith] [a to warn of danger] see also,

duty of can·dor.definition: [-kan-dər]a duty obligating directors of a corporation to disclose all material facts known to them about a transaction when they are seeking shareholder approval

duty of care.definition: a duty to use due care toward others in order to protect them from unnecessary risk of harm

duty of fair representation.definition: a duty obligating a labor union to represent the employees in its collective bargaining unit fairly and in good faith

duty of loy·al·ty.definition: a duty obligating directors of a corporation to refrain from using their positions to further their own interests rather than the interests of the shareholders (as by self-dealing or fraud)

fiduciary duty.definition: a duty obligating a fiduciary (as an agent or trustee) to act with loyalty and honesty and in a manner consistent with the best interests of the beneficiary of the fiduciary relationship (as a principal or trust beneficiary)
